title: Apprentice levy will not solve skills crisis, warns CBI
text:

Mon, Jul 13, 2015, 00:05 BST - UK Markets open in 7 hrs 55 mins Apprentice levy will not solve skills crisis, warns CBI By Alan Tovey | Telegraph – 1 hour 6 minutes ago Print 
Business lobby group says levy introduced in Budget is unlikely to deliver highly-skilled workers 
The Chancellor’s plan to levy large businesses to fund apprenticeships may not deliver the highly-skilled workers needed by industry, Britain’s biggest business lobby group has warned. 
The CBI argues that the new scheme, sketched out in last week’s Budget, is unlikely to deliver workers with the advanced skills needed to rebalance the economy towards high-tech sectors and manufacturing. 
The Government has pledged to deliver 3m apprenticeships by the end of this parliament but new research by the CBI raises doubts over whether workers with the skills businesses need will be produced. 
A CBI survey of more than 300 companies, which between them employ more than 1m staff, revealed the scale of the skill challenges facing industry. 
Two out of three businesses said they expect to need more staff with higher skills over the next few years, but more than half of these companies do not think they will be able to locate enough people with the required training. 
Just 2pc of apprenticeships started in 2013-14 were at the advanced level, which leads to qualifications equivalent to higher education. Katja Hall, CBI deputy director-general, said: “The Government has set out its stall to create a high-skilled economy, but firms are facing a skills emergency now which threatens to starve economic growth.”
